Questions: 39*. Show that, for x > 0, the graph of function y given by the equation y + |y| - x - |x| = 0 is the bisector of the first quadrant, whilst for x ≤ 0 the function is many-valued and its "graph" is the set of points of the third quadrant (including its boundary points).
Answers: Let x > 0 and y > 0, then y + y - x - x = 0; y = x (the graph is the bisector of the first quadrant). Let x > 0 and y < 0, then y - y - x - x = 0; x = 0 (the graph is the negative half of Oy). Let x < 0 and y > 0, then y + y - x + x = 0; y = 0 (the graph is the negative half of Ox). Let x < 0 and y < 0, then y - y - x + x = 0 (an identity; the "graph" is the aggregate of points of the third quadrant).

Questions: A tower has the following shape: a cylinder of radius R and height 2R is mounted on a right circular truncated cone with base radii 2R (lower) and R (upper); a hemisphere of radius R is mounted on the cylinder. Questions: Give the domain of definition of the function y = log (ax² + bx + c).
Answers: If b² - 4ac > 0 and a > 0, the function is defined throughout the real axis except for the interval x₁ ≤ x ≤ x₂, where x₁ and x₂ are the roots of the trinomial. If b² - 4ac > 0 and a < 0, the function is defined only for x₁ < x < x₂. If b² - 4ac ≤ 0 and a > 0, the function is defined throughout the real axis. If b² - 4ac ≤ 0 and a < 0, the function is defined nowhere. Finally, if b² - 4ac = 0, the function will be defined throughout the real axis except for the single point x = -b/(2a), if a > 0, and is nowhere defined if a < 0.

Questions: Find graphically the roots of the equation eˣ sin x = 1, e ≈ 2.718, lying between 0 and 10; give an approximate general formula for the remaining roots. The accuracy required is 0.01.
Answers: x₁ ≈ 0.59, x₂ ≈ 3.10, x₃ ≈ 6.29, x₄ ≈ 9.43; in general x ≈ nπ (n > 2).

A function of an integral argument takes the values u₁ = 0.9; u₂ = 0.99; u₃ = 0.999; ..., uₙ = 0.999...9 (n times); ...
What is the value of lim uₙ as n→∞? What must be the value of n for the absolute value of the difference between uₙ and its limit not to exceed 0.0001?

Find lim uₙ as n→∞. What must n be for the difference between uₙ and its limit to be less than a given positive ε?
Show that uₙ = (n-1)/(n+1) tends to unity as n increases indefinitely. As from what n is the absolute value of the difference between uₙ and unity not greater than 10⁻⁴?

The function vₙ takes the values v₁ = cos(π/2)/1; v₂ = cos(π)/2; v₃ = cos(3π/2)/3; ...; vₙ = cos(nπ/2)/n; ...
Find lim vₙ as n→∞. What must n be for the absolute value of the difference between vₙ and its limit not to exceed 0.001?
Does vₙ take the value of its limit?
Answers: lim vₙ = 0; n ≥ 1000. vₙ is sometimes greater than, sometimes less than, and sometimes equal to its limit (the last when n = 2k+1, where k = 0, 1, 2, ...).

Questions: The general term of the sequence u₁ = 1/2, u₂ = 5/4, u₃ = 7/8, u₄ = 17/16, ... has the form (2ⁿ-1)/2ⁿ if n is odd, and (2ⁿ+1)/2ⁿ if n is even. Find lim uₙ as n→∞. What must n be for the absolute value of the difference between uₙ and its limit not to exceed (i) 10⁻⁴; (ii) a given ε?
Show that the sequence uₙ = (4n²+1)/(3n²+2) tends to a limit equal to 4/3 whilst increasing monotonically on indefinite increase of n. As from what n is 4/3 - uₙ not greater than a given positive ε?

Show that uₙ = √(n²+a²)/n has a limit equal to unity as n increases indefinitely. As from what n is |1 - uₙ| not greater than a given positive ε? What is the nature of the variation of variable uₙ in the limit?
Answers: n ≥ a/√(ε(2+ε)); the sequence is decreasing.

Questions: A function vₙ takes the values ('binomial coefficients') v₁ = m, v₂ = m(m-1)/1·2, v₃ = m(m-1)(m-2)/1·2·3, ..., vₙ = m(m-1)(m-2)...[m-(n-1)] / 1·2·3...n, ..., where m is a positive integer. Find lim vₙ as n→∞.
Answers: lim vₙ = 0; vₙ reaches its limit with n = m+1, since, as from this value, vₙ = 0.

Questions: Show that the sequence uₙ = 1 + (-1)ⁿ has no limit as n increases indefinitely.
Show that the sequence uₙ = (2ⁿ + (-2)ⁿ)/2ⁿ has no limit as n increases indefinitely, whilst the sequence vₙ = (2ⁿ + (-2)ⁿ)/3ⁿ has a limit.
Do the following sequences have limits? (1) uₙ = n sin(nπ/2); (2) uₙ = sin(nπ/2)/log n (n>1)?
The sequence u₁, u₂, ..., uₙ, ... has limit a ≠ 0. Show that lim (uₙ₊₁/uₙ) as n→∞ = 1. What can be said about this limit if a = 0? (Give examples.)
Answers: With a=0 this limit can equal any number or be nonexistent.

Questions: Given y = x², when x→2, y→4. What must δ be for |x-2| < δ to imply |y-4| < ε = 0.001?
Let y = (x²-1)/(x²+1). When x→2, we have y→3/5. What must δ be for |x-2| < δ to imply |y - 3/5| < 0.1?
Let y = (x-1)/(2(x+1)). When x→3, we have y→1/4. What must δ be for |x-3| < δ to imply |1/4 - y| < 0.01?
Show that sin x tends to unity as x→π/2. What condition must x satisfy in the neighbourhood of the point x=π/2 for 1-sin x < 0.01?
When x increases indefinitely the function y = 1/(x²+1) tends to zero: lim (1/(x²+1)) as x→∞ = 0. What must N be for |x| > N to imply y < ε?
As x→∞, y = (x²-1)/(x²+3) → 1. What must N be for |x| > N to imply |y-1| < ε?
A function uₙ takes the values u₁=3, u₂=5, u₃=7, ..., uₙ=2n+1, ... Prove that uₙ is a large order magnitude as n→∞. As from what n is uₙ greater than N?
Show that the general term uₙ of any arithmetic progression is a large order magnitude as n→∞. (When is it positive and when negative?) Does this statement hold for any geometric progression?
Answers: uₙ is a positive large order magnitude if the difference of the progression d > 0, and is negative if d < 0. The statement holds for a geometric progression only when the denominator of the progression has an absolute value greater than 1.

Questions: As x→0, we have y = (1+2x)/x → ∞. What condition must x satisfy for the inequality |y| > 10⁴ to hold?
Show that the function y = x/(x-3) is of large order as x→3. What must x be for |y| to be greater than 1000?
When x tends to unity, the function y = 1/(x-1)² increases indefinitely. What must δ be for |x-1|<δ to imply 1/(x-1)² > N=10⁴?
The function y = 1/(2x-1) is infinitely large as x→0. What inequality must x satisfy for |y| to be greater than 100?
As x→∞, we have y=log x → ∞. What must M be for x > M to imply y > N=100?
Which of the basic elementary functions are bounded throughout their domain of definition?
Answers: sin x, cos x and all the inverse trigonometric functions.

Questions: Is the function y = x²/(1+x⁵) bounded throughout the real axis? Is it bounded in the interval (0, ∞)?
Is the function y=log sin x bounded throughout its domain of existence? Answer the same question for y=log cos x.

Show that the functions y=x sin x and y=x cos x are not bounded as x→∞ (indicate for each of them at least one sequence of xₙ such that yₙ→∞). Do the functions become infinitely large? Sketch the graphs of the functions.
Answers: For example, xₙ = π/2 + 2nπ, xₙ' = 2nπ; no.

Questions: For what values of a is the function y = aˣ sin x unbounded as x→+∞ (x→-∞)?
Answers: If a > 1, the function is unbounded (but not infinitely large) as x → +∞; it tends to zero as x → -∞. If 0 < a < 1, the function is unbounded as x → -∞ (but is not infinitely large); it tends to zero as x → +∞. With a = 1 the function is bounded throughout the real axis.

Questions: Show that y = x/(x+1) → 0 as x→0. What condition must x satisfy for the inequality |y| < 10⁻⁴ to hold?
Prove that the function y = √(x+1) - √x tends to zero as x→∞. What must N be for x>N to imply y<ε?

Write each of the following functions, which has a limit as x→∞, as the sum of a constant (equal to the limit) and a function; prove that the latter function is an infinitesimal as x→∞: (1) y = x³/(x³-1); (2) y = x²/(2x²+1); (3) y = (1-x²)/(1+x²).
uₙ takes the values u₁ = 1/4, u₂ = 1/4 + 1/10, u₃ = 1/4 + 1/10 + 1/28, ..., uₙ = 1/(3+1) + 1/(3²+1) + ... + 1/(3ⁿ+1), ... Show that uₙ tends to a limit as n→∞.
Answers: Compare uₙ with the sum of the terms of the geometric progression 1/3, 1/9, 1/27, ..., 1/3ⁿ.

Questions: Show that the sequence uₙ: u₁=√6, u₂=√(6+u₁), ..., uₙ=√(6+uₙ₋₁)... has a limit and find the limit.
A function is defined as follows: y=0 for x<0; y=x for 0≤x<1; y=-x²+4x-2 for 1≤x<3; y=4-x for x≥3. Is this function continuous?

Three cylinders of the same height 5 m and base radii 3, 2 and 1 m respectively are set up end to end. Express the cross-sectional area of the figure obtained as a function of the distance of the section from the lower base of the bottom cylinder. Is this function continuous? Draw its graph.
Answers: f(x) = 9π for 0 ≤ x ≤ 5; f(x) = 4π for 5 < x ≤ 10; f(x) = π for 10 < x ≤ 15. The function is discontinuous at x = 5 and x = 10.

Let f(x) = { -2sin x, if x ≤ -π/2; A sin x + B, if -π/2 < x < π/2; cos x, if x ≥ π/2. Choose the numbers A and B so that f(x) is continuous; draw its graph.

At what points have the functions y = 1/(x-2) and y = 1/(x+2)² discontinuities? Draw the graphs of the functions. Describe the difference in the behaviour of the functions close to their discontinuities.
The function f(x) = (x²-1)/(x³-1) is not defined at x=1. What value must we give f(1) in order to make f(x) continuous at x=1?
What sort of discontinuities do the functions y = (sin x)/x and y = (cos x)/x have at x=0? Show the nature of the graphs of the functions in the neighbourhood of x=0.
Answers: The function y = sin(x)/x has a removable discontinuity at the point x = 0, y = cos(x)/x has a discontinuity of the second kind (infinite).

Questions: Investigate the continuity of the function given by: y = |x|/x at x≠0, y=0 at x=0. Draw the graph of the function.
Answers: The function is discontinuous for x = 0.

Questions: How many discontinuities (and of what kind) has the function y = 1/log|x|? Sketch its graph.
Answers: The function has three points of discontinuity. At x = 0 the discontinuity is removable, whilst it is of the second kind (infinite) at x = ±1.

Questions: The function y = arc tan(1/x) is not defined at x=0. Is it possible to further define f(x) at x=0 in such a way that the function is continuous at this point? Sketch the graph of the function.
Answers: No. As x→0 from the right, f(x) → π/2, whilst as x→0 from the left, f(x) → -π/2.

Questions: Investigate the continuity of the function given by f(x) = sin(π/(2x)) at x≠0, f(0)=1. Sketch the graph of the function.
Answers: The function is discontinuous at x = 0.

Questions: Sketch the graph of f(x) = x sin(π/x). What value must we give f(0) in order to make the function continuous everywhere?
Investigate the character of the discontinuity of the function y = 2^(-2^(1/(1-x))) at x=1. Could y be defined at x=1 in such a way that the function would become continuous at x=1?
Answers: No. As x → 1 from the right, y→ 1, whilst as x → 1 from the left, y→ 0.

Questions: Investigate the nature of the discontinuity of the function y = (2^(1/x)-1)/(2^(1/x)+1) at the point x=0.
Answers: As x→0 from the right, y→ 1, whilst as x→0 from the left, y→ -1.

Questions: A function f(x) is defined as follows: f(x) = (x+1)2^(-(|x|+1/x)) for x≠0 and f(0)=0. Verify that the values of f(x) lie exclusively between f(-2) and f(2) in the interval -2≤x≤2 and that f(x) is nevertheless discontinuous (at what point?). Sketch its graph.
Answers: The function is discontinuous at x = 0 (discontinuity of the first kind).

Questions: Investigate the continuity of the function y = 1/(1+2^(tan x)). What sort of graph has the function?
Answers: The function has discontinuities of the first kind at the points x = (π/2)(2k + 1).

Questions: A function is defined thus: if x is a rational number, f(x)=0; if x is irrational, f(x)=x. For what value of x is the function continuous?
Answers: The function is continuous at x = 0, and is discontinuous for x ≠ 0.

Questions: Investigate the continuity and draw the graphs of: (1) y = x - E(x); (2) y = 1/(x-E(x)); (3) y = (-1)^(E(x)). Function E(x) is equal to the greatest integer not greater than x (see also problem 59).
Answers: All three functions are discontinuous when x is equal to an integer (positive or negative) or zero.

Answers: Write the polynomial in the form xⁿ(a₀ + a₁/x + ... + aₙ/xⁿ) and investigate its behaviour as x → ±∞.

Answers: Draw schematically the graph of the function y = a₁/(x-λ₁) + a₂/(x-λ₂) + a₃/(x-λ₃), and investigate its behaviour in the neighbourhood of points λ₁, λ₂ and λ₃.

An infinitesimal uₙ takes the values u₁=1, u₂=1/2, u₃=1/3, ..., uₙ=1/n, ..., whilst the corresponding values of infinitesimal vₙ are v₁=1, v₂=1/2!, v₃=1/3!, ..., vₙ=1/n!, ... Compare uₙ and vₙ; which is of the higher order of smallness?
Answers: vₙ is of the higher order of smallness.

Questions: The function uₙ takes the values u₁=0, u₂=3/8, u₃=8/27, ..., uₙ=(n²-1)/n³, ... whilst the corresponding values of vₙ are v₁=2, v₂=5/8, v₃=10/27, ..., vₙ=(n²+1)/n³, ... Compare these infinitesimals.
Answers: uₙ and vₙ are equivalent infinitesimals.

The hypotenuse of a right-angled isosceles triangle of adjacent side a is divided into n equal parts and straight lines drawn from the points of subdivision parallel to the adjacent sides. The step line AKLMNOPQRTB (Fig. 16) is thus obtained. The length of this step line is equal to 2a for any n, i.e. the limit of its length is equal to 2a. Answers: It does not follow from the fact that the step line tends to merge with the straight line (in the sense of their points approximating) that the length of the step line tends to the length of the segment.
